pros: The recent changes in leadership have really made a difference. You have the ability to share your ideas with leaders and the culture is shifting to one that is more flexible and collaborative. There are many opportunities to get involved in making the hospital system a place to be proud to come to work. There are several Caregiver Resource Groups led by the DEI team where caregivers can join to work together and make changes to Sinai's culture while also helping achieve the system's goals. Other pros are that the PTO is good and some positions still have work-from-home flexibility.
cons: The fact that it is a safety-net hospital means that there will always be challenges. While Sinai is making waves of improvements to catch up to other hospital systems, working with limited resources is still a challenge.

pros: Sinai Chicago truly cares for the underserved. While I have worked here, I have cared for refugees, immigrants, homeless, young and older, etc. Even though L&D is a specialty, they welcomed me without any prior L&D experience. I was extremely grateful since L&D was always my most cherished specialty during nursing school. My orientation was at least 13 weeks. I was able to obtain a new certificate while on orientation such as NRP and attended a basic EFM course which was offered for free. After COVID, we have welcomed many new grads which is unheard of in L&D. The staff is also diverse! Tuition Reimbursement is offered which I used to obtain my BSN. New RNs can become certified as soon as 6 months and take advantage of their certification differential. They also provide the usual benefits such as 403 b with matching contributions, PTO, and Medical / Dental / Vision.
cons: Parking garage is undergoing renovations and this causes parking shortages. On-call is mandatory but you do not get called in as much since staffing numbers are great.

job_title: Manager Quality and Information for Women and Children's departments in Chicago, IL
pros: I am very excited and fortunate to be part of Sinai Chicago. Sinai embraces anyone who is passionate about improving care to the surrounding community. The Leadership team is very supportive, and their first priority is to promote patient safety with evidence-based medicine. They have also provided opportunities to become a better leader in my role. I am given the chance to mentor and develop staff, lead quality projects that improve patient care and outcomes. This is where I see that what I do can make a difference. Work Life balance is also a priority as we are provided with benefits and also are recognized for our individual contributions that we make thru the Sinai Stars program. There is so much room to grow and advance in different departments. Overall, a great place to work!
cons: Definitely the parking-Shortage of spaces due to garage improvement project that will end quite soon!!;)

pros: Great place to work. Awesome coworkers. Very diverse.
cons: Old hospital. Old equipment. Management never around.

review_title: Why You Should Choose Sinai Chicago as Your Place of Employment
pros: 1. Strong multidisciplinary approach to address health and social needs. 2. Ability to serve a vulnerable population with complex healthcare disparities and inequities. 3. Great learning environment for all
cons: Working in a safety net hospital system has its own unique challenges. Yet, it has taught us how to utilize our resources wisely.

pros: One of the things that I enjoy the most about working here is being able to see our efforts, positively effect the community we serve.
cons: The biggest con would be not being able to take the pain and hurt away from our patients.

pros: Great culture overall and team
cons: The pay is not in par with similar locations nearby

job_title: Pulmonary Function Technologist in Chicago, IL
pros: Great team / co-workers / Friendly staff
cons: Upper management disengaged with workers and primarily focused on increasing work load without regard to industry standards.

review_title: Great Place to work, grow your career, and learn
job_title: Drug Diversion Investigator in Chicago, IL
pros: There are so many reasons to work for Sinai Chicago, I work here because I truly embrace the community, the values, and the care/services Sinai Chicago provides. I started out as a pharmacy technician intern student 10 years ago. I knew I always wanted to work at Sinai, because of the care they provided to my family and friends. As a CPhT, I have experienced and grown so much in my career, and the management here provided that opportunity to grow. They provided development, resources, and engagement. Sinai Chicago stands with the community they serve. Excellent care and respect are some of the values I see daily.
cons: There are really no downsides working here for me. I do become sad when people outside of the community talk disrespectfully about the hospital and the location. It is always my pleasure to provide facts to them, about the level of care that caregivers at Sinai Chicago give. From the Cooks all the way to the CEO.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor/Psychotherapist in Chicago, IL
pros: Opportunity to work in a hospital.
cons: A very poor onboarding, glitchy/old technology, sarcastic management and lack of support.

pros: Good coworker and teamwork and less strict management
cons: Non organized place and short turn over staff

job_title: Community Health Worker in Chicago, IL
pros: Very friendly and noble community. It's a great place to start your career.
cons: The place is physically falling apart and there is a low retention rate. There's hardly any succession planning. It's a hard place to work at so it's common for people to leave. It's definitely a wonderful experience and will get you on the right track if you're resilient and honest. A good place to start.

pros: Average pay for the city
cons: Overworked, always short staffed, not good benefits or 401k

pros: Some people still care. Pay
cons: Most people are there for the check. A lot of unfair politics Management is not supportive, they just do what it takes to keep the doors open. I felt as though I could make a change but I lost hope. It’s was an extremely toxic environment. Most problems are ignored even when brought to light.

pros: Will be working so let’s see if salary is justifiable with their working conditions.
cons: None yet, will work there soon.

pros: Awesome attention to rewarding employees and keeping communication lines open top down.
cons: Communication styles is not comprehensive across all administrators.

pros: great coworkers to work with
cons: Classic where all direct services are people of color, and the supervisor is always a white person. They do not even post their position internally.

pros: Consistency in hours and bonuses
cons: Busy work environment, no support

job_title: MEDICAL CODING MANAGER in Chicago, IL
pros:
Good opportunity for advancement
Teaching hospital
People
Community involved
cons:
Favoritism
Benefits are okay
Neighborhood not safe at times

review_title: Low stress in a High stress place.
job_title: Computer Tomography Technologist II in Chicago, IL
pros: No tick tacky Bull poo.
cons:
Equipment old. Very low-state of the art for a Big City Hospital.
Can See how bad Social Equity can affect a whole side of a City.
What Bigotry, Racism and the hiring practices(police, fire, union jobs) can do over generations to colored people. What did they think was going to happen?

pros: You gain lots of experience
cons: Lots of work for very low pay

job_title: Human Resources Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Free care at the hospital or its clinics
cons: Old building, still paper based

pros: Good pay and some good coworkers
cons: Its always Short staffed. Management promises changes and nothing is done.

pros: Lots of sick patients with end stage disease. High patient load makes transitioning into attending life smooth.
cons: Will often come close to 70hr work weeks.

pros: Accepts new grads, good place to learn and form your nursing skills
cons: Benefits aren’t the best and always short staffed

pros: Very flexible and understanding of life circumstances. There is a great culture, people are friendly, the organization supports staff to learn .
cons: Very outdated and run down facilities. Not a lot of opportunity to get promotions. Benefits are not great and you only get 6 holidays a year.

pros: location, close to downtown chicago. has a bus stop and train near by.
cons:
management, staff
summer festivals cause traffic and we can no longer park for free at Douglass Park

review_title: difficult place to work but great learning
pros: helping the underserved population, great coworkers, good place to learn clinical skills, self scheduling
cons: high acuity in patient population, staffing issues, low ancillary resources, most days without CNAs,

pros: People at SUHI are very close and respectful. There i a great work culture and leadership is very flexible with your schedule.
cons: Facilities are very very run down, and compensation is not competitive.

pros:
Pt population is complex and challenging
Rotations help you build skills
cons:
There is no end in sight for rotations - no permanent positions ever available
Near-impossible bonus program 
Location safety

job_title: Primary Care Physician in Chicago, IL
pros: Provide excellent health care for those in communities where there is health inequality. Show great sensitivity to culture, racial and ethnic biases
cons: Need to utilize the experiences and opinions of the care providers. I did not see opportunities for promotion and advancing

pros:
Departments work well together to achieve goals. 
Caregivers are always available to help each other.
cons: Career advancement takes longer than expected

review_title: You may regret it but you'll learn a lot
pros:
Free parking in unsafe parking facilities
So busy those 12 hours go by really fast
Lots of CPD presence
cons:
No or rarely breaks or lunches
Those 12 hours will be spent mostly on your feet
Lots of CPD presence
Way too many other cons to list here

pros: Great people great place to be.
cons: Relaxed environment can become an issue for productivity

pros: Mission, Supporting High-Need Communities, Patient, Community Engagement
cons:
Do not accept a position here. Executive and Senior Leadership is disengaged and/or out-of-touch. It just rolls downhill from there. The career opportunities sound good but notice the turnover rates at positions of all levels. There is a culture of fear, gossip, and lack of training or resources. The career stagnation is palpable within the first 6 months of being there, especially for minority candidates. 

Complete lack of understanding or acknowledgment of high-level skills needed to complete job requirements. Co-workers and superiors backstab and claim credit for your work. Looking for a new position right now.

pros: Good coworker and diversity culture, great mission
cons: Old computer system and shortage of staff, and expensive parking fees for super busy

pros: Staff are very nice people to work with
cons: Management is terrible. Don’t know your job or theirs. Makes everything complicated.

job_title: Full Stack Developer in Chicago, IL
pros: fine teammates, remote for now
cons: Things move a bit slow, location is not great

review_title: The pay was fine but the workplace environment was toxic.
pros: I received great health education training.
cons: There was very hard to receive a promotion and the supervisors were unstoppable until they were investigated and fired.

pros: Some people were nice, if that
cons: Management doesn't care about anyone

pros: Experience galore, but poor compensation.
cons: Overworked, under compensated. I performed the work of 3 positions while there, and while I appreciated the training and experience, I was not compensated for my performance.  I made the same pay as others who did less than half of what I did.  Plus I was willing and on MANY occasions DID work doubles, nights, weekends and holidays that I was not required to just to fill the needs of the department, yet I was not compensated for such. HOWEVER, I learned so much, and met a lot of very memorable people, a few of whom became my friends.  I am proud to say that I worked there, and I know that I was able to make a difference.  It was very rewarding to know that my efforts helped in some small way to ease the transitions, challenges, and pain of many people.

job_title: Mental Health Worker in Chicago, IL
pros: Within this department - able to pick my hours M-F, benefits are decent. Accumulate ~6 hours per pay period
cons: Will feel burnout very quickly. At times, you may feel like management doesn't support you.

pros: Flexible work schedule  and went to school full time
cons: Dangerous as you sometimes had to use restraints

review_title: Very disappointed in the opportunities for advancement.  Promotions do not seem to be merit or credentials based.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: There are good people at this hospital.  People who care about the patients and the community.  Because of the level of longevity (many employees have 5 - 20 years) there is often a family atmosphere and co-workers interact outside of work.   There are lives saved every day by people deciding their work is more important than their pay and career opportunities.
cons: People are routinely not held accountable for doing less than a competent job.  Too many employees have a civil servant mentality.  Management seems to be immune to accountability as well.  The hospital was just informed it lost over $2million from poor patient billing/intake.  No one lost their job and no manager took responsibility.  A current project is also being implemented in a poor manner.  Again, the responsible parties are immune to being held responsible.  I'm shocked an organization with so little cash on hand can function in this manner.  36+ people were recently laid off - but some folks who poorly do their jobs were promoted.  If you are looking to advance with an MBA go to a different hospital or industry.

review_title: 20 year Executive - understand the inner workings.
pros: SVP/CFO has kept hospital afloat.
cons:
Management by intimidation to the highest levels of this Organization.  Accountability non-existent.  Will not be termed for poor work output but will be 'downsized' if you were to speak out against patient endangerment, staffing, or generally anything that gets back to Karen Teitelbaum, CEO.  Actually watched Karen ostracize a manager by speaking in a meeting loud enough for everyone to hear her conversation to a VP sitting next to her - while the Director was sitting across the table.
That does not bode well for an environment of change, or one that constantly tries to bring in 'new blood' to improve moral.
Change the top (CEO to VP) to a for-profit mentality and watch hospitals quality scores change.

pros: Decent pay, cafeteria food is good and adequately priced.
cons: Management says they want to provide quality health services to the community, but that mission never quite comes across.  Staff members are disrespectful and rude to patients and never corrected. Good public health based programs are allowed to fall by the wayside.  Found that management had no idea what I did in my position.  Many of the processes within the system were antiquated and slow to change.  The benefits...although at first glance the benefits seem comprehensive, the health insurance was woefully inadequate.  Both PPO options only allowed you to go to Sinai/Access or a few other hospitals for full coverage...the coinsurance and deductible were extremely high, and I actually went into a lot of debt due to medical bills working at the hospital.  Go figure!

pros: Opportunities to help vulnerable people, and make a positive impact on medically under-served communities.
cons: The organizational culture devalues employee concerns. Leadership pays lip service to “work-life balance,” but you should expect to work long hours, and then attend a public event on your day off. You will be expected to perform well without adequate financial and staff resources. You will find some of the infrastructure is crumbling due to lack of funds.  You might get laid-off due to financial crises; a director who had relocated from out of state to work there got laid-off recently, just eight months after starting his position.  At the same time, they also laid-off good people who'd been with the organization for 20 or more years.  The organization has announced that it's closing its children’s hospital, which probably means more layoffs.

review_title: Admirable mission, antiquated campus and technology.
pros: You are helping the people that need you most. Low SES, undocumented, uninsured etc. Most patients thankful. Staff from physicians to housekeepers all friendly and working towards the mission. Once you work here (in a clinical role) you can work anywhere.
cons: This hospital does not have enough beds for the amount of patients that need to be here. Staffing is awful, turnover high in some areas. Limited resources. Old technology, old equipment. Actual buildings falling apart. Constant frustration due to things that don't work correctly or just aren't available. Management disorganized, nepotism rampant. Certain employees getting away with not working, constantly leaving early, showing up late etc tolerated by management who looks the other way.

review_title: great place to work, but can be stressful!
pros: excellent mission, hospitals are vital part of the community, room to grow & opportunites for professional development, great people and co-workers, challenging patient population but your positive impact can be very strong and rewarding
cons: financial challenges, frequent changes in leadership, capital/infrastructure upgrades are needed, too many random healthcare consultants advising senior leadership, limited resources so you may have to wear multiple hats which is not always a bad thing

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist in Chicago, IL
pros: The mission statement is a good one.
cons: Overall the facility is not kept very clean in the places where laboratory workers work. The restrooms are horrible and just emptying trash cans does not mean much. I will be reporting this to the health department very soon as soon as I take some more pictures.  I will also be leaving as well. Sad that you will lose great employees because of this.  I am also concerned about the cafeteria workers who do not look very clean to be around and preparing food. The standards must be improved.

pros: Co workers and most nurses are very nice and caring.
cons: Some nurses talk about the other nurses, and some nurses expect me to remind them to do their job, then blame me when they forget. The parking garage is so coveted there is a waitlist, but you need to pay for parking if a spot becomes available. This is not a safe neighborhood so street parking is not always an option.  I need to buy my own supplies (pens, notebooks, binders, etc) and if I happen to leave anything on my desk, its gets borrowed; never to be returned. Using my own $ to buy supplies when I am not not getting paid well is just not right.

review_title: Great place to work if you want to give back to the community and have fun.
pros: You can help the community.  Mt Sinai is located in predominantly lower socioeconomic neighborhood.  The patient population is within the full spectrum but there are a number of unisured.  It is a great place to work because it feels like you are helping out the community.
cons: The campus is old.  The hospital predominantly serves an poor socioeconomic population which puts some fiscal constraints on the management in maintaining the physical plant.  You will not find someone playing th piano in the lobby nor mahogany wood tables and chairs in the lobby.

pros: Very old facility serving poor and sometimes violent neighborhood. Management is working hard to improve continuing nursing education and to recruit and maintain high-quality employees. In some ways, very supportive atmosphere. General atmosphere is very friendly and much of upper management seems very dedicated to the hospital and its mission.
cons: Starting salary for nurses somewhat below average. Some floors have a very nasty, almost toxic, culture with little cliques and a lot backbiting (even within cliques.) Many of the nurses seem bitter and burned out.

review_title: You have believe in it, to want to be here, and even then sometimes you'll wonder what you're thinking.
pros: Fighting the good fight, delivering health care to those in need who otherwise may receive medical attention.
cons: The inadequacies of the antiquated and quite often dilapidated physical structure coupled with the the equally inadequate technological and informational infrastructure make an already difficult job even harder.

review_title: I work with  continuity patient care. I took pride and enjoyed what I did.  The hospital benefits are great.
job_title: Biller Expediter I in New York, NY
pros: Well if you apply yourself to take your work responsibilities serious there is room to grow. It worth working here.
cons: It's a challenge and everything has to be balanced out in give what is most important priority.

pros: A lot of patients are very troubled since they are in a low income community & you will be put in a lot of random situations to grow professionally.
cons: Many nurses dont want to be there. Their passion for nursing turned into a money making machine & they arrive like they don't want to work there.

review_title: Mount Sinai is your typical non-profit hospital in the middle of Gangland Chicago.
job_title: Physician Assistant Surgery in Chicago, IL
pros: Great for first timers. You will get to see and experience situations that you will never be in again.
cons: As a specialized surgical professional you will be paid at the rate of a PCP.  There is no room for salary growth if this is your first job out of school.  You will be paid a salary that compensates a 40 hour work week, but you will work 50-60 hours on average.

pros: Job stability.  As long as you keep quiet and do what you're told you have job security.
cons: Although you're able to keep a job, there is no professional growth.  Managers are not supportive of transferirng to other positions.  The people who grow within the system are very few.  They are mostly in the same department and their manager has helped them to maneuver the system.

pros: Caregivers truly care for the patients they support.  Most are here for the right reasons.
cons: Leadership does not give lower level employees information of current system goals.  No clear information associated to health of organization, but messages point out doom-and-gloom.  Trying to use technology to solve problems that are organizational/operational

review_title: Not the place to go if you're looking to grow.
pros: The only pro I can think of is the Autonomy.
cons: Coworkers are unreliable.  When people say they will do something they rarely follow through.  Facilities not well kept or clean.  No training or advancement opportunities.  Once you get there you're stuck doing what you're doing until you decide to leave.  No raises in several years.

pros: It's a great place to get experience. You see everything there. Depending on your manager, it is easy to transfer to other units for more/different work experience.
cons:
The patient load can be heavy a lot of times. You talk to management about it being too heavy and the acuity too high, but they don't do anything to change it. 
It's often hard to find the equipment/supplies you need to do your job.

review_title: Not a bad place to work...
pros: Great environment; very family oriented, they don't ask a lot out of you, even though the benefits suck it's a pretty low stress environment
cons: People tend to get holed up and try to get job security, often rude and discourteous staff, incompetent administrative people (all areas), the hospital seems to just be throwing money away, please keep a lot of the office areas clean (environmental staff doesn't seem to like to clean)

pros: They leave you alone to wk independent
cons: No structure, supervisors and managers can or will not give you answers.  You as the low man on the totem pole or new  one on the block are left to fly solo.  There is nothing in writing or manuals to follow. What ever is is on paper is probably from 1970 and has not been updated!

pros:
-Easy to transfer/promote within the hospital
-Some caregivers are amicable and understanding of patients
-Pay is mediocre
cons:
-Incompetent Managers
-Diversity issues
-Poor patient quality and service
-Management bullies its employees

I've been here almost a full year and I've noticed a lot of issues that are bringing down the hospital, especially the Radiology department. The lack of care from management and the chairman baffles me and it has been destroying the workplace morale. Employees back stab and sneak around to get other employees fired. This hospital has a huge turnover rate; I have been here almost a full year and witnessed 4 doctors leaving. Be mindful when applying to this company.

review_title: Facebook friends and ignorance need only to apply
pros: None, except how not to act in a hospital
cons: This is a culture of Facebook friends and ghetto behavior only need only to apply the EDI management and the Lee ddtech are all friends if you don't kiss but if you don't act ghetto they will become like dogs too well I'll meet they would try to destroy you they threaten you very passive aggressive behavior conniving one-sided very racially biased towards a lot of people and there's nothing you can do about it so if you need to work this is definitely not the place to apply

job_title: A Position of Some Authority in Chicago, IL
pros: There are pockets of good, sincere people working here committed to serving an underserved patient population.
cons: The organization claims transparency, but is broadly dishonest to all employees. Pay is woefully under market, work conditions are abysmal, the physical plant is old and falling apart, professional standards are so far out of reach as to be laughable. According to Crain's Chicago Business, Alan Channing recently received a 1.5 MILLION dollar retention bonus while the administration cries "We are a Poor Hospital" at every meeting and so they cannot (fill in the blank - give raises, improve benefits, provide patients with working televisions, rid the hospital of rodents...). Nurses lack basic supplies and equipment to keep patients safe, pest are bold and rampant, managers are arrognat, distant and lack basic leadership skills. The data system in hopelessly out of date and no financial, budget, patient or staffing data is accurate or reliable, Senior Leadership walks the halls in designer clothes, knows the first names of most employees and pats their backs  - and then lays off them off  in the next breath. Consultants are in and out the door making unrealistic suggestions that are ultimately ignored anyway, but as long as the consultants get the money - who cares. That is, if they ever actually pay the consultants. All staff know to cash their checks IMMEDIATELY, because it is never really certain that the money for the employees will actually be there on payday. And don't even get me started on the laughable benefits - except for the senior management of course!

pros: A place that walks the talk when it comes to Making Lives Matter and taking care of the communities they serve!
cons: Reimbursement from the state makes it hard to procure necessary equipment.  High turnover in some leadership roles.  I do maintain a high level of respect for the c-suite team.

review_title: Not the worst place to work, just mediocre
pros: co-workers were very pleasant for the most part
cons: Budget cutbacks caused a lot of job losses without warning to certain employees. thought they could have at least given a heads up

pros:
I love the organization, very instrumental to the company and a great asset.
I have also learned much in the years i have been here
cons: Everyday is a new experience, you have to adapt accordingly.

review_title: The work environment was hospitable and accommodating up to the point when Holy Cross Hospital was acquired.

cons: There is preferential treatment for Sinai Health System-train hospital and pharmacy staff.

pros: Really get to learn how an inner city hospital functions.Good solid management with competent medical professionals.
cons: The hospital is not well kept ...dingy! Lousy parking that is expensive!

pros: it's an honor to be a Caregiver at a hospital.
cons: The system is broken beyond repair

review_title: Don't work there if you value your sanity, your economic security, and your career.
pros: The mission would be a pro except that the organization lacks the financial resources and capabilities to fulfill it.
cons: The organization is in chaos overall; turnover at the management level is very high thus projects remain unfinished; layoffs are frequent; quality of care is subpar; the infrastructure is decrepit.

pros: A lot of over time offered.
cons: Management is hard to get ahold of if you work night shift.

pros: I was able to get a registry position which allowed me to make my own schedule.

job_title: Sterile Processing Supervisor in Chicago, IL
pros:
Hard working management team. 
Top of the line patient care.

Not many opportunities for advancement.
Raises were horrible and not based on performance.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician/Training Instructor in Chicago, IL
pros: Great pay. Good stepping stone Hospital to start at.
cons: Too many people trying to be the Boss. MESSY older women starting trouble.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New York, NY
pros: 12 HRS shifts/ union/pension/ education reimbursement/ Up To Date with technology.....
cons: Don't appreciate nurses all they care about is patient satisfaction.

pros: Good place to get experience. Challenging but worth the effort
cons: Poor management.. Needs a tune up.

pros: Open environment at the unit, possibility to develop new ideas

pros: Sinai does great things for the community

pros: Able to advice my knowledge and practice in the field of ultrasonography

review_title: Translator/Interpreter x3yrs & Clinical Research Coordinator x1yr

review_title: Best Place to Work in NYC

pros: good hours for part time employment.

pros: Fast pace, trauma center, growing health system

pros: Great place to work for a career starter.
cons: Pay isn't all that great, but Sinai is surrounded by big competitors.

pros: educated and dedicated staff, therapy dog and cool equipment

pros: Flexability in work enviroment, lots of communication on every level

pros: Assisted people to make positive changes in their lives.

pros: Urban healthcare, needed for the community it serves.

pros: Good teaching hospital. Acquired great experience

pros: Good very great place to work at

pros: Great hospital to work at in IL

pros: Some good employees, some good benefits, very few good leaders, good emergency room docs for trauma, most nurses are hard working

pros: You have a job...I guess thats about it
cons: Nurses laugh at patients when they are very ill.  They dont take patients serious.

pros: good place to work and friendly environment
cons: salary and benefits can use a face lift
